In the event the Commission took on only the grant-in-aid to the History of Parliament Trust; the Treasury still makes the grants to the international bodies, now including the British-Irish Inter-Parliamentary Body."

At that time, there was no funding threat to our bodies from the Treasury, and their view was that if it ain't broke, don't fix it. However, the vulnerability of grant in aid from the Treasury has been made clear, and I hope that the House of Commons Commission will provide the protection that we need. The Tebbit report recommends
"that the House of Commons Commission should take over responsibility for making grants-in-aid to the four inter-parliamentary bodies."

My right hon. and learned Friend the Leader of the House is a member of the House of Commons Commission. She was present earlier, and I hope that my hon. Friend the Deputy Leader of the House, will ask her and let me know whether the Leader of the House will support the application of the four inter-parliamentary groups to receive funding and financial scrutiny from the Commission. She may have already have put the question, and if so I hope that she will be able to reply during her response.

The right hon. Member for Maidenhead (Mrs. May), who represents the Conservative party on the Commission, was in the Chamber earlier, and I ask her hon. Friend the Member for North-West Cambridgeshire (Mr. Vara) to talk to her to see whether he can persuade her to support what would be a right and sensible decision by the Commission to take responsibility for our bodies. That would be in the interest of Parliament, and it would certainly be in the interest of the bodies. I hope that a favourable decision will be made in good time before Christmas so that we are aware of the financial situation that we expect to be in next year, and can plan our affairs accordingly.

speech.speakeroffice: The Deputy Leader of the House of Commons
speech.p: It is a pleasure to serve under your chairmanship this afternoon, Mr. Weir.

I have been a Member of Parliament for only two and a half years, and it is only six months since I was asking what I hope were difficult questions of the hon. Member for North Devon (Nick Harvey) about the House's environmental performance, and giving evidence to Sir Kevin Tebbit in preparation for his report. When I did so, I did not expect to find myself in my present position with its ensuing responsibilities.

I am reminded of someone I knew in the Foreign Office who sent an instructing telegram to someone who was conducting trade negotiations in Paris. The person who was supposed to undertake the negotiations fell ill, so the person I knew had to fly to Paris, undertake the negotiations, send a reporting telegram home to London, fly back, read the reporting telegram, and thank the person who had done the negotiations. His final telegram began, "You spoke well."

I shall begin with green issues, which are one of hon. Members' main concerns. Clearly, it is important that the Commission take a balanced approach to green issues. The hon. Member for North Devon (Nick Harvey) described significant improvements in recent years that were made against the difficult background of an awkward building that was not designed to cope with modern technology and the ever-increasing demands placed on it. There are some excellent statistics at the back of the 29th report, and the Commission will notice that over five years, despite significant improvements, the estate's energy use per square meter has increased, and that levels of waste recycling have not changed significantly. I am sure that it will take those things into account.

When we look at the work of the Commission and the responsibilities of the House authorities, we can see how different issues interrelate. I see that much more clearly than I did was an ordinary Member. Several hon. Members mentioned the importance of improving IT and the improvements that have been made following the establishment of the Parliamentary Information and Communications Technology Department. Improvements in off-site IT and communications support for Members will be beneficial, because the pressure to provide more staff in the Palace will be reduced. Improvements on a number of fronts can be made by pulling only a small number of levers.

We heard about the increasing number of people who work in the Palace. Again, at the back of the report there are some interesting statistics on Members' staff and the staff payroll. Hon. Members may wish to learn about the detail underlying those numbers, and I have secured some information that may further inform the Commission's considerations. The latest estimate for the number of people occupying the estate is 4,700, including 646 Members, 1,850 House staff, 1,250 Members' staff and 950 other individuals, who can be disaggregated into 475 policemen or other security staff, 175 members of the press, nearly 80 people who work on other services, 120 contractors, and a small number of members of other groups including, for example, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. When we look at the pressure on accommodation and what can be done about it, it is helpful to consider all of the groups that contribute to it.

I thank you, Mr. Weir, and all right hon. and hon. Members who have taken part in the debate. We have had a very good discussion about and look at the various areas of work in which the Commission and the House service are involved. We were delighted to welcome the Leader of the House, who has recently come on to the Commission and brings, as she pointed out, the benefit of many years' experience in the House. I also pay tribute to the Secretary of State for Justice and Lord Chancellor, the former Leader of the House, who served on the Commission for a year and was a very good member of it. He had very interesting ideas and priorities, which he pursued with great determination. We will miss him because he contributed very much to the Commission's work.

The right hon. and learned Lady was right to augment what I said about the Tebbit report with the attention that she gave to his points about the use of resources, the need for the House always to ensure that it is receiving good value for taxpayers' resources, and the need to evaluate what we do, for example, through a scorecard system.

The hon. Member for North-West Cambridgeshire (Mr. Vara), speaking for the Opposition, was right to say that some hon. Members remain dissatisfied with the ICT services. The Administration Committee has quantified and measured that and flagged it up, but I hope that we have reassured him that it is recognised and that more work is taking place on that front. He urged us to pursue a more green procurement agenda, and I will certainly ensure that the Officers of the House take that on board.

The hon. Gentleman referred to the new security passes—I have taken delivery of mine just today. There is some confusion on the part of some hon. Members, although not the hon. Gentleman, who think that the PIN—personal identification number—system will be used at every point throughout the estate where the card is required. That is not true. Only at the external perimeter will the PIN system be needed, but he makes a good point that if the cards were in any sense inhibiting the ability of hon. Members to get to Divisions, we would have to attend to that as a priority.

I am sure that the hon. Gentleman's points about reforms of European scrutiny will be noted in the appropriate places. He also warned against targets for targets' sake, which was a commendable thought. He let us off the hook slightly by saying that we could have priorities instead of targets, but I took the point that he was making.
Yes, indeed—quite so.

I thank the Committee for its ongoing work on ICT issues. The aspiration for the facilities outside the Palace to be as good as those inside is absolutely right. As the Deputy Leader of the House said, that will overcome some of the pressure to have more and more staff located inside the House.

I was also very relieved that the hon. Member for Aberdeen, North and not me found himself in the firing line over giving priority to MPs in accessing the services of the House. I welcome the fact that it sounds as though he has had a constructive meeting with staff to examine the complexity of some of these issues. I think that my hon. Friend the Member for North Southwark and Bermondsey acknowledged that in some cases common-sense solutions will be needed to try to make things better for everyone.

My hon. Friend considered many aspects of the work of the House. He referred to the possibility of our ending up with a temporary partial evacuation of the building to facilitate some of the works that need to take place. It is, as he acknowledged, far too early to make even any preliminary judgments as to whether that will be necessary or desirable. There has been confusion in some of the press reporting that the need to replace the roof might exacerbate that. I am not in any sense minimising the significance of that task, which will be huge, but I think that the replacement of the mechanical and engineering infrastructure will be more disruptive of the work that goes on inside the building. That is absolutely enormous in its scope. The basic infrastructure of the building is more than a little aged and will have to be replaced. If a point comes at which we are replacing entire heating and plumbing systems, there will have to be quite careful consideration of how that can be done incrementally or whether, if we try to keep going with business as usual through such major works, there is a danger that we will have one or two unfortunate consequences, not least to the public purse. As we have already acknowledged, we have to use the public's money wisely.

My hon. Friend's points about diversity were well made, and I will ensure that they are given attention by the relevant parts of the administration. He referred to a green shopping list and the need for stickers asking us all to ask ourselves whether we need to use the lifts. I take his point. I do not know the answer to his question about recycled paper, but I will place that in front of the appropriate Officers.

My hon. Friend referred to facilities for cycling. I myself have just resumed cycling after a brief interval of some 30 years and I take his point that we need facilities around the place. We have taken the view, on security advice, that we can allow only passholders to bring their bicycles within the boundary of the parliamentary estate. Beyond the perimeter, there are other issues, in that this area of Parliament square and Whitehall, with the Government Departments in it, is in itself a security zone in which considerations are a little more complicated than they might be for any other London street. However, I acknowledge the desirability of what he describes.

My hon. Friend's suggestion that we use some of our staff as a representative group to test services is very good. He referred to putting together packages for visitors from other parts of the country, which was a very interesting idea. I am entirely in sympathy with what he said about lobbies and the green card system, and his points about more joint working with the House of Lords. I take the point in his gentle chiding about the Tebbit process, in that we decided to embark on a review that was limited to a test of how effective the changes from the previous review, the Braithwaite review, had been and that the recommendations that Sir Kevin has come forward with are by no means earth shattering. Therefore, I will feed my hon. Friend's view through to my fellow Commission members. At the very least, what he has recommended should be given favourable consideration.

The hon. Member for City of York (Hugh Bayley), in his capacity as chair of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, spoke about the work of the international bodies and flagged up the 2011 centenary conference. It is not my place to give rise to unjustifiable hopes, but I will say to him gently that although perhaps the devil will be in the detail, he and his colleagues can consider that they have cleared one of the higher fences on the course by getting a positive recommendation from the Finance and Services Committee.

The Deputy Leader of the House, whom we welcome in her new role, also made the point about ICT. She gave us a detailed breakdown of the different categories of users of the parliamentary estate, who number in total some 4,700 in the Commons part of the estate. The categories into which she broke that down included even the press, for whom facilities have recently been refurbished. One can only hope that the new comfort in which they find themselves will stop them writing such beastly things, but that is probably more of a hope than an expectation.

The Deputy Leader of the House also pressed for improvements to arrangements for visitors coming from far away, pointing out that some visitors to Parliament from her constituency were making their first visit to London. Having driven through her constituency last Sunday, I appreciate that the communication difficulties from there to London are comparable to those in my own, and we must do all that we can to help more visitors come here.

I hope that I have addressed some of the main problems mentioned. If there are any outstanding points, I shall respond to hon. and right hon. Members. To echo the words of others, I thank the staff of the House for everything that they do to improve the efficiency of our work. We are all very grateful to them.
Question put and agreed to.
Adjourned accordingly at half-past Four o'clock.
